question.name: Question 1
question.text: How long should records on identification procedures carried out on customers be kept for?
question.correctans: Seven years after the designated service was last provided to the customer
question.choices: Seven years after the designated service was last provided to the customer|In perpetuity|Until the business relationship ends, or the customer opens a new account with the organisation|They can be destroyed immediately

question.name: Question 2
question.text: What must you do every time an identification procedure is carried out for a customer?
question.correctans: You must make a record of the procedure
question.choices: Report it to AUSTRAC|Ensure any information you obtain is made publicly available|You must make a record of the procedure |Destroy all evidence of any information you obtain

question.name: Question 3
question.text: When must your organisation keep records about an international funds transfer?
question.correctans: When it is involved in the transfer with two or more other organisations
question.choices: When it learns that its competitors made such a transfer|When it makes the transfer with any individual organisation|When it makes the transfer with at least three other organisations|When it is involved in the transfer with two or more other organisations

question.name: Question 4
question.correctans: A deposit account that a bank holds at a foreign or correspondent bank for the purposes of international payments
question.choices: A deposit account for astronauts|A deposit account that a bank holds at a foreign or correspondent bank for the purposes of international payments |A deposit account that money launderers hold in order to conceal illegally obtained money|A bank account in Switzerland

question.name: Question 5
question.text: What of the following is NOT KYC information that you must collect in relation to individual customers?
question.choices: Full name|Passport ID number|Residential address|Date of birth

question.name: Question 6
question.text: After collecting KYC information about a company, what details must you verify?
question.choices: Full name of the company|Whether the company is listed as proprietary or public|ACN issued to the company|All of the above

question.name: Question 7
question.text: Complete the sentence. Safe harbour procedures only apply to\u2026
question.choices: \u2026 sole traders|\u2026 large companies|\u2026 low to medium-risk individual customers|\u2026 high-risk individual customers only

question.name: Question 8
question.text: What should organisations do in relation to any safe harbour procedures they adopt?
question.correctans: Document them in the AML program
question.choices: Remove all evidence of them|Document them in the AML program|Keep them private and confidential|Avoid revising them to minimise confusion

question.name: Question 9
question.text: Which of the following documents should NOT be used to verify a customer's date of birth in a safe harbour procedure?
question.choices: Any printout of a passport |A certified copy of a national identity card|An original copy of a letter from Centrelink|A certified copy of a birth certificate

question.name: Question 10
question.text: If the customer is an individual, you can assume the customer and beneficial owner are the same person unless reasonable grounds exist to think otherwise. True or false?

question.name: Question 11
question.text: If the customer and beneficial owner are of medium or lower ML/TF risk, what kind of safe harbour procedure to identify them?
question.choices: A document-based procedure only|An electronic-based procedure only|Both document-based or electronic-based procedures|Safe harbour procedures cannot be used in this circumstance

question.name: Question 12
question.text: Fill in the blank. The KYC identification procedure is _____ a customer who is an Australian government entity.
question.correctans: \u2026 not required if your organisation has already collected and verified information about\u2026
question.choices: \u2026 a complicated process if your organisation has already collected and verified information about\u2026|\u2026 mandatory and enforceable under the law for\u2026|\u2026 not required if your organisation has already collected and verified information about\u2026|\u2026 particularly easy to perform for\u2026

question.name: Question 13
question.text: What must you do in relation to a politically exposed person who is Australian and has a high ML/TF risk?
question.correctans: Acquire senior management approval before you establish or continue a business relationship with them
question.choices: Acquire AUSTRAC approval before you establish or continue a business relationship with them|Acquire senior management approval before you establish or continue a business relationship with them|Automatically establish or continue a business relationship with them|Automatically refuse to establish or continue a business relationship with them

question.name: Question 14
question.text: An enhanced due diligence program is NOT necessary in which of the following situations?
question.correctans: When a designated service is provided with a low ML/TF risk
question.choices: When the customer has a high ML/TF risk|When reportable suspicious matters arise|When a designated service is provided to a politically exposed foreign dignitary|When a designated service is provided with a low ML/TF risk

question.name: Question 15
question.text: Which of the following is part of ongoing due diligence?
question.choices: A KYC information timeframe|An enhanced CDD program|A transaction monitoring program|All of the above
